title: In an iOS app, your user interface can take on one of a few different general shapes and sizes. These are defined using
size classes

inline_content.Text: In an iOS app, your user interface can take on one of a few different general shapes and sizes. These are defined using
, which are available through a view or view controller’s

title: Apple defines two size classes:
regular
b
and
compact
b
. Each of these size classes are available on both axes of the device (
horizontal
b
and
vertical
b

). Your app may exist in any these four states throughout its lifetime. As a shorthand, developers often describe a size class combination by saying or writing the two size classes, with the horizontal axis first: “Compact/Regular” describes an interface that is horizontally compact but vertically regular.

title: In your app, use methods on the UITraitEnvironment protocol to check your current size class and respond to changes:

inline_content.Text: In your app, use methods on the UITraitEnvironment protocol to check your current size class and respond to changes:

title: Both UIView and UIViewController conform to UITraitEnvironment, so you can look at your current trait collection and handle changes in subclasses of either.

inline_content.Text: Both UIView and UIViewController conform to UITraitEnvironment, so you can look at your current trait collection and handle changes in subclasses of either.
